name: Climate IQ
description: Test your environmental knowledge with data-driven trivia.

questions.prompt: How long does a plastic bottle take to decompose in a landfill?
questions.explanation: Plastic bottles can take 450+ years to decompose. Some scientists estimate up to 1,000 years.
questions.funFact: Every piece of plastic ever made still exists somewhere on Earth.

questions.prompt: Glass is 100% recyclable and can be recycled endlessly.
questions.explanation: Glass can be recycled over and over without any loss in quality or purity.

questions.prompt: What percentage of the world's ocean pollution is plastic?
questions.explanation: Approximately 80% of marine debris is plastic, mostly from land-based sources.
questions.funFact: By 2050, there could be more plastic than fish in the ocean by weight.

questions.prompt: Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to run a TV for 3 hours.
questions.explanation: Recycling aluminum uses 95% less energy than making new aluminum from raw materials.

questions.prompt: Which country recycles the most waste?
questions.explanation: Germany recycles about 67% of its waste, the highest rate of any major country.

questions.prompt: How many trees does recycling one ton of paper save?
questions.explanation: Recycling one ton of paper saves 17 trees and 7,000 gallons of water.

questions.prompt: Food waste in landfills produces methane, a greenhouse gas.
questions.explanation: Food decomposing anaerobically in landfills produces methane, which is 80x more potent than CO2 over 20 years.

questions.prompt: What is the most commonly littered item in the world?
questions.explanation: Cigarette filters are the most littered item globally â€” 4.5 trillion are discarded each year.
questions.funFact: Cigarette butts contain plastic (cellulose acetate) and take 10+ years to decompose.

questions.prompt: How much of the plastic ever produced has been recycled?
questions.explanation: Only about 9% of all plastic ever produced has been recycled. 12% has been incinerated, and 79% is in landfills or the environment.

questions.prompt: What does the number inside the recycling symbol on plastic mean?
options: How many times it can be recycled
questions.explanation: The number (1-7) identifies the type of plastic resin, not whether it's recyclable.

questions.prompt: What percentage of US household waste could be composted?
questions.explanation: About 30% of what we throw away is food scraps and yard waste that could be composted.

questions.prompt: How much water is saved by recycling one ton of paper?
questions.explanation: Recycling paper saves massive amounts of water compared to making paper from virgin wood pulp.

questions.prompt: Biodegradable plastics break down in regular landfills.
questions.explanation: Most biodegradable plastics need specific conditions (heat, oxygen) found only in industrial composting facilities, not landfills.

questions.prompt: What is the biggest source of greenhouse gas emissions globally?
questions.explanation: Energy production (electricity and heat) accounts for about 25% of global greenhouse gas emissions.

questions.prompt: How many plastic bags are used worldwide each minute?
questions.explanation: An estimated 1 million plastic bags are used every minute worldwide.
questions.funFact: The average plastic bag is used for just 12 minutes.

questions.prompt: Wishcycling (putting non-recyclable items in recycling hoping they get recycled) actually helps.
questions.explanation: Wishcycling contaminates entire recycling loads, causing more waste, not less.

questions.prompt: How long does a glass bottle take to decompose in a landfill?
questions.explanation: Glass is incredibly durable and can take over 1 million years to decompose naturally.

questions.prompt: What percentage of e-waste is properly recycled globally?
questions.explanation: Only about 17% of electronic waste is formally collected and recycled worldwide.
questions.funFact: E-waste contains more gold per ton than gold ore.

questions.prompt: How many pounds of trash does the average American produce per day?
questions.explanation: The average American generates about 4.4 pounds of trash per day, or about 1,600 pounds per year.

questions.prompt: Recycling creates more jobs than landfilling the same amount of waste.
questions.explanation: Recycling creates 10x more jobs than landfilling â€” about 36 jobs per 10,000 tons vs 6 for landfills.

questions.prompt: What year did the first plastic recycling symbol appear?
questions.explanation: The resin identification coding system was introduced in 1988 by the Society of the Plastics Industry.

questions.prompt: Which plastic type is most commonly recycled?
questions.explanation: PET (#1) is the most recycled plastic, commonly used for water and soda bottles.

questions.prompt: What is 'downcycling'?
questions.explanation: Downcycling means recycling a material into something of lesser quality than the original.

questions.prompt: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is a solid island of trash.
questions.explanation: It's actually a vast area of microplastic particles suspended in the water â€” not a visible island.
questions.funFact: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is twice the size of Texas.

questions.prompt: What percentage of the world's oil production goes to making plastics?
questions.explanation: About 8% of the world's oil production is used to manufacture plastics.

questions.prompt: Which country first banned single-use plastic bags?
questions.explanation: Bangladesh became the first country to ban thin plastic bags in 2002 after they clogged drainage systems and worsened flooding.

questions.prompt: How much food is wasted globally each year?
questions.explanation: About 1.3 billion tons of food is wasted annually â€” roughly one-third of all food produced.

questions.prompt: Microplastics have been found in human blood.
questions.explanation: A 2022 study found microplastics in 77% of human blood samples tested.
questions.funFact: Humans may ingest up to 5 grams of microplastic per week â€” the weight of a credit card.

questions.prompt: What is the carbon footprint of a single cheeseburger?
questions.explanation: A single cheeseburger produces about 3.5 kg of CO2 when you include farming, processing, and transportation.

questions.prompt: Which material has the highest recycling rate in the US?
questions.explanation: Lead-acid batteries (car batteries) have a 99% recycling rate â€” the highest of any material.

questions.prompt: What is the term for designing products for easy disassembly and recycling?
questions.explanation: All three terms describe approaches to designing products with end-of-life recycling in mind.

questions.prompt: What temperature is needed for industrial composting?
questions.explanation: Industrial composting reaches 130-170Â°F, hot enough to kill pathogens and break down tough materials.

questions.prompt: Sweden imports trash from other countries to fuel its waste-to-energy plants.
questions.explanation: Sweden recycles so effectively that it imports waste from Norway and other countries to power its WTE plants.
questions.funFact: Less than 1% of Sweden's household waste goes to landfill.

questions.prompt: What does EPR stand for in waste management policy?
questions.explanation: EPR makes manufacturers responsible for the end-of-life management of their products and packaging.

questions.prompt: How much energy does recycling aluminum save vs making new?
questions.explanation: Recycling aluminum saves 95% of the energy needed to make new aluminum from bauxite ore.

questions.prompt: What is 'chemical recycling' of plastics?
options: Mixing plastic with chemicals for disposal
questions.explanation: Chemical recycling breaks polymers back into their base monomers, allowing creation of virgin-quality plastic.

questions.prompt: The fashion industry produces more carbon emissions than international aviation and shipping combined.
questions.explanation: The fashion industry accounts for about 10% of global carbon emissions â€” more than aviation and shipping combined.

questions.prompt: What is the theoretical maximum recycling rate possible for a modern economy?
questions.explanation: Experts estimate about 85% is the practical maximum, as some materials degrade or are contaminated beyond recovery.

questions.prompt: How many times can paper fiber be recycled before it's too short?
questions.explanation: Paper fibers shorten with each recycling cycle. After 5-7 times, they're too short to hold together.

questions.prompt: What percentage of ocean plastic comes from just 10 rivers?
questions.explanation: Eight of the top 10 rivers are in Asia, and two are in Africa. Better waste management in these areas would dramatically reduce ocean plastic.
